results.title: The Western garden
results.creator_credit: Luc Weber, Philippe Guerdat and Libraprim S A
results.brief_description: This documentary examines the history of gardens in the Western world, exploring their various functions over the centuries and how their constant state of change reflects the societies that revolve around them. Gardens - literally, pieces of land removed from their natural environments - have existed as sites of refuge, worship and meditation, served as accessories to political power, and provided humans with new ways of expressing art. From the cloistered medicinal gardens of medieval Europe to modern open parklands enclosed by cityscapes, gardens document “as much of the spirit of a period as its literature, its paintings or its sculpture”. Some of the stunning gardens explored in more detail include those at Villandry (France), Vaux-le-Vicomte (France), Hadrian’s Villa (Tivoli, Italy), Villa Garzoni (Collodi, Italy) Queen Eleanor’s Garden (Hampshire, UK), Hampton Court Palace (Surrey, UK), and the Royal Botanic Gardens (Kew, UK).

results.title: The West. Eps 7 and 8: The Geography of hope. One sky above us
results.creator_credit: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode seven (1877-1887): “The Geography of hope” (85 mins) - By 1877, American conquest of the West was almost complete leaving the Chinese, Mexican-Americans and the Indians no longer welcome - either assimilate or get out. Discrimination also extended to the African-Americans once the Federal Troops withdrew from the South. The grassy plains became desirable for farming and grazing, railroads were being established, and small settlements and farming communities were expanding and developing into large cities and states. In the meantime, the Indian people were being forced off their land and into reservations. Harsh restrictions were put on the Indians and by law they were compelled to change their identity, to assimilate, speak English, attend American schools (military style) and were banned from practising any of their ceremonies and rites. Children as young as five were taken away from their parents, often never to be seen again. Episode eight (1887-1914): “One sky above us” (111 mins) - The final episode of this magnificent series. Covers the 1887 Dawes Act which resulted in the breaking up of Indian tribes and their ownership to land; the shooting of Chief Sitting Bull and the slaughter of Lakota Indians at Wounded Knee in 1890; mining corporations, industrialization and ecological destruction during the mid 1880’s; harnessing of the Owens River resulting in the Los Angeles Reservoir in 1913. Throughout this series we have followed the tragic history of the Indians, and in particular, the man of peace, Chief Joseph of the Nez Perce tribe. In Chief Joseph’s words “Whenever the white man treats the Indian as they treat each other, then we will have no more wars. We shall all be alike — brothers of one father, and one mother, with one sky above us and one country around us, and one government for all. Then the Great Spirit who rules above will smile upon this land, and all people may be one people”. Narrated by Peter Coyote.

results.title: The West. Eps 3 and 4: The Speck of the future. Death runs riot
results.creator_credit: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode three (1848-1856): “The Speck of the future” (85 mins) - The discovery of gold in California in 1848 changed the West forever. Gold diggers from all over the world came to seek their fortune. The gold rush also brought thousands of American immigrants travelling in wagon trains and by boat. Wherever gold was discovered, the pattern set in California repeated itself - Americans rushed in, towns sprang up, and Indian tribes found themselves outnumbered in their own lands. This episode talks about the “Forty-niners”; Kit Carson; the Fort Laramie Treaty of 1851; the devastating effect of the invasion of foreigners to the Native Indian tribes - the slaughter, the famine and the diseases; San Francisco (the West’s first full-fledged city), and Levi Strauss. Episode four (1856-1868): “Death runs riot” (85 mins) - A myth had grown up about the West: “you could escape and be free”. The Americans began moving West in increasing numbers, staking claims on Indian land, clearing the land, building towns and cities. But with it came slavery, the American nation’s most divisive issue, bringing war and bloodshed and eventually the Civil War. Mexican-Americans also suffered persecution and removal by murder or otherwise at the hands of the Texas Rangers. The Cheyenne Peace Chiefs led by “Black Kettle” faced a losing battle with the whites and war and revenge would rage for many years. Narrated by Peter Coyote.
results.title_for_label: The West. Eps 3 and 4: The Speck of the future. Death runs riot

results.title: The West. Eps 1 and 2: The People. Empire upon the trails
results.creator_credit: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The West”.
Episode one (to 1806): “The People” (88 mins) Begins the historical mapping of a vast expanse of land (over 2 million square miles) which stretches from the Mississippi to the Pacific Ocean, from the northern plains to the Rio Grande and which for a thousand generations belonged to more than 3 million Indians of various nations including the Comanches, the Hidatsas, the Cheyenne, the Apache, the Zunis, and the Hopi. Describes the lives and cultures of some of the tribes, their rituals, sacred sites, beliefs and customs. The first Europeans to set foot in the West was in 1528 by a small group of shipwrecked Spanish soldiers lead by Alvar Nunez Cabeza de Vaca. This episode tells of the Spanish invasion and conquest, their religious fervour and hunger for land and the devastation which their wars, famine and diseases brought upon the native Indian. Follows through to October 1804 when American explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark set off on an expedition to explore the Missouri River and hopefully find a north-west passage across to the Pacific Ocean. Episode two (1806-1848): “Empire upon the trails” (84 mins) Deals with the control and destiny of the West. By 1821, two Republics had claimed a sizeable part of the West - the United States (half of the West) and the Republic of Mexico (South-west and California). England still had outposts in the Pacific North-west and several Indian nations held fast to their lands. Covers the Battle of the Alamo, the arrival of the Mormons, the formation of the States of Texas and California and the addition of Oregon, Washington and Idaho to the Union, the Mexican-American War and the relocation of some 90,000 Indians. In 1848 gold was discovered - “Nothing in the West would ever be the same again”. Narrated by Peter Coyote.
results.title_for_label: The West. Eps 1 and 2: The People. Empire upon the trails
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV

results.title: The West Indies: Caribbean region 1
results.brief_description: Historical overview of the West Indies. Shows the principal West Indies Islands, their strategic and economic value to the western world, their topography, climate, industries, and the peoples who live there today.

results.title: The West Indies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
Discusses the varied population, terrain, resources and opportunities for economic growth of the West Indies, modern trends toward industry, and traditions of large plantations and small farms raising a large variety of semi-tropical crops.

results.title: The West
results.creator_credit: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV
results.brief_description: A historical account through to 1914 of the American West presented as an eight-part documentary series for television. Includes archival footage, stills, newsreels, diaries and artefacts, and commentary by historians, writers and anthropologists (American and Native American), with spectacular images of the landscape and haunting background music. Narrated by Peter Coyote.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jody Abramson, Michael Kantor, Stephen Ives, Florentine Films, Insignia Films, Time-Life Video & Television and WETA-TV

Narrated by Peter Coyote.

Narrated by Peter Coyote.

results.title: The Well of the saints
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A traditional Irish folk drama by John M. Synge, set in the east of Ireland, two or three centuries ago. The satiric theme - that sometimes it is better to preserve one’s illusions than to face reality - is expressed through the episode of Martin and Mary Doul’s miraculously restored sight. Part of the “Short play showcase” series.

results.title: The weeping earth: salt in South Eastern Australia
results.brief_description: Dr Jim Bowler introduces a program addressing the scourge of the Australian land - salt - a side effect of settlement and clearing. Discusses the situation before European settlement and examines why salt is such a problem by looking at the history of the Australian landscape.
